animal_concentrations.References: (1) Koistinen J et al; Environ Sci Technol 29: 2541-7 (1995) (2) Paasivirta J et al; Chemosphere 16: 1781-90 (1987)
animal_concentrations.Value: Bis(2,4-dichlorophenyl)ether was detected in ringed seals (Phoca hispida saimensis) from Lake Saimaa and one seal (Phoca sibirica) from Lake Baikal, Finland at concentrations of 6 to 11 ng/g lipid weight; seals were collected in 1988 and 1992, respectively(1). Bis(2,4-dichlorophenyl)ether was not detected in white-tailed eagle (Hailaetus albicilla) from the Baltic(2).

environmental_biodegradations.Value: Biodegradation data in soil or in water were not available. (2012, SRC)

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Huestis SY, Sergeant DB; Chemosphere 24: 537-45 (1992) (2) Nimi AJ et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 13: 1133-8 (1994) (3) Koistinen J et al; Chemosphere 19: 527-30 (1989) (4) Koistinen J et al; Chemosphere 27: 149-56 (1993) (5) Koistinen J et al; Environ Sci Technol 29: 2541-7 (1995)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Bis(2,4-dichlorophenyl)ether was detected in carp (Carpiodes carpio) at 24 to 170 pg/g and in pike (Esox lucius) at 30 to 137 pg/g; fish were collected from Whitby Harbour, on Lake Ontario(1). Bis(2,4-dichlorophenyl)ether was detected in lake trout (Salvelinus namaycush) collected in the fall of 1992 from Lake Ontario and Lake Huron at a trace to 5.2 and not detected to 0.4 ug/kg(2). In the same survey, trout from Lake Superior did not contain bis(2,4-dichlorophenyl)ether(2). Bis(2,4-dichlorophenyl)ether was detected in walleye (Stizostedion vitreum) from Lake Erie at not detected to 0.4 ug/kg(2). Bis(2,4-dichlorophenyl)ether was not detected (detection limit <5 pg/g) in salmon caught in the Central Gulf of Bothnia in 1986 and in the Baltic Sea near Gothland in 1986, but was detected in salmon caught in the Gulf of Finland in 1987 at 0.005 to 0.013 ng/g(3). Bis(2,4-dichlorophenyl)ether was not detected (detection limit <5 pg/g) in cod liver fat; cod were caught at the Arctic Coast of Norway in 1987 and 1988(3). Bis(2,4-dichlorophenyl)ether was detected in pike and lake bream sampled from the Kymijoki River, Finland at 9-12 and 10 pg/g fresh weight, respectively; sample dates were not provided(4). Pike, sampled from the Kymijoki River, Finland were found to contain <7 ng/g lipid weight of bis(2,4-dichlorophenyl)ether, samples were collected in 1993(5).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: Niimi AJ et al; Environmental Toxicology and Chemistry; 13 (7): 1133-1138 (1994)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Tetra-to decachlorodiphenyl ether (CDPE) concentrations were measured in take trout and walleye, fish that represent the higher trophic levels in the North American Great Lakes. GC-MS analyses indicated the mean total CDPE concentrations were 4, 16, 57, and 126 ug/kg in whole fish from Lakes Superior, Huron, Erie, and Ontario, respectively. The number of known and unidentified congeners detected above the 0.4-mug/kg detection limit ranged from six to 24 congeners among the lakes, and this number increased with the total concentration of CDPEs. The Cl6 homologue represented 46 to 61% of total CDPEs in Lakes Huron, Erie, and Ontario, and the Cl5, Cl6, and Cl7 homologues represented 78 to 93% of total CDPE concentrations.

The presence of 26 congeners of polychlorinated diphenyl ethers (PCDEs) was investigated in salmon from three locations in Finland. In addition to salmon, one chlorophenol wood preservative (Ky-5) and one fly ash sample were analyzed for PCDEs. Concentrations of PCDE congeners in salmon muscle measured by high resolution gas chromatography/low resolution mass spectrometry ranged from <0.02 to 2.4 ng/g fresh weight. The major components of tetra- to octachlorinated PCDEs in salmon were one TeCDE (22'44'-), two PeCDEs (22'44'5- and 23'44'5-) and three HxCDEs (22'44'56'-, 22'44'55'- and 22'344'5-). The Baltic salmon caught from the Simojoki River had higher levels of PCDEs than the Atlantic salmon from the Tenojoki River or salmon from Lake Saimaa in South-Finland. Same PCDE congeners which were abundant in the wood preservative were also detected in salmon, whereas PCDE congeners in the fly ash were different from those in salmon or in Ky-5.

mechanism_of_action.References: Rissanen K et al; Acta Cryst C44: 1644-46 (1988)
mechanism_of_action.Value: Polychlorinated diphenyl ethers occur, together with related chlorinated aromatics, as impurities in various commercial chlorophenol preparations... and are now turning up in environmental samples... The nontoxicity of the polychlorinated diphenyl ethers /such as bis(2,4-dichlorophenyl) ether/ compared to polychlorinated biphenyls has been explained by the non-planarity of the diphenyl ethers. Thus they do not fit into the rectangular (3 x 10 angstrom) dioxin receptor as do the toxic biphenyls...

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Koistinen J et al; Environ Sci Technol 29: 2541-7 (1995)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Sediment samples collected in 1993 from the Kymijoki river, Finland contained bis(2,4-dichlorophenyl)ether at 1 ng/g dry weight(1).
